From the people who brought you Elder Scrolls.

												Hunted: The Demon’s Forge is an action hack and slash game. Developed by inXile Entertainment and published by Bethesda, releasing on PS3, Xbox 360 and PC in Mid-2011. Gameplay in Hunted can be done either single player or co-op, whether it is online, or split screen. You play as either E’lara or Caddoc. E’lara specialises in using range weapons whilst Caddoc is the sword and board of the pair. Both of the characters have access to casting spells but these play a smaller part in the combat than you would think due to mana constraints. The hack and slash type combat system is really fun, and the range combat is even better. As you kill enemies they will drop fragments of shards, collect enough shards and you will get a skill point. You can use the skill point to purchase new abilities and upgrade the abilities as well. By the end of the game you will more or less have all of the skills so it doesn’t matter too much which you pick initially.  If you are playing the game solo, you have the option at checkpoints to change which character you are in control of. In general, the computer AI is fairly intuitive at using your partner, helping you in battle etc.I played Hunted on 4k, with graphics ramped up to max, and it does look really good. The environments you are fighting in, the backdrops and character models all look very impressive. What I was a little let down by is the animation. It just seems to of been done very lazily, using the wrong animation at the wrong time, such as when you are moving through a narrow hole that has nothing above your head, the animation that is used, is clearly just the stock “Generic animation when moving through object” as the characters will show hand movements as if they are holding objects above their head. It just felt really sloppy and looked very unprofessional at times. Other than the animation, the visuals department of Hunted is better than average. Whilst the game has voice acting, the male actor doesn’t quite hit the right notes for me. Feels very generic meat head style and sometimes the words don’t quite match up with the character’s mouth so again, an animation issue.  E’lara’s voice actor is slightly better, but again the issue with animation crops up again. Sound effects for weapons are really good though. Soundtrack is somewhat forgettable, even now after just completing the game, no music seems to have stood and stuck in my head.I started out the game on the medium difficulty level and found that to be too easy, so I restarted and put the difficulty on the max setting, and this really does give you a challenge. You really have to make use of every single potion drop, every ounce of mana and above all else, make use of your characters roll ability. I can’t help but think it would still have been really easy had I been playing with another person rather than the AI though.Whilst you are exploring the dungeons, caves and fortresses, you will find weapon wracks, depending on which character you are in control of, if you destroy said weapon wrack, you will get a piece of loot which is relevant for your character, so E’lara will usually get a bow, and Caddoc will usually find a sword or shield. The looting aspect of the game is probably one of my favourites, because well; who doesn’t like loot in games? Whilst the weapons and armour don’t have massive amounts of variety on, you normally only get two stats. For your bow it is usually speed and damage, same for swords but you can also get armour plated shoulder pads which adds a bit extra armour stat on for your character. I finished Hunted in just over nine hours.  I found that to be an acceptable length, whilst I wasn’t bored at the end of the game, I didn’t have a craving for any more though. The story is bland and very forgettable. There is a small amount of character development, but because they are both so generic in their stereotypes, I found it very hard to care about either of them.  There is a high replay ability factor with this game though. Having only played it on single player and I focused my time on using E’lara, I could quite easily replay the game and get a whole different experience just from using Caddoc. You can also get probably at least one more run throughout of the game on co-op mode too. So you can probably reach about 25 hours’ worth of content if you push it. Technically, there were a few problems. Like I said above, I was playing on 4k resolution with graphics ramped up to max. Whilst playing I noticed there to be a significant stutter in the game when you are entering a new area. At first I thought it was purely a resolution thing, so I dropped it down to 1440p but it was still the same, so I tried again to 1080p and the stutter was still there. I even turned down all of the options to minimum and the stutter still existed. So to put it shortly, I am not sure what causes this stutter, given that you are changing areas quite frequently you will suffer from it a lot too.  Another issue I had, was the camera when your character is sprinting, it just jolts up and down all over the place and actually gave me a head ache because of it. Luckily you don’t need to sprint that often thankfully. To sum up, Hunted: The Demon’s Forge has some nicely presented game play and mediocre visuals. The story is forgettable and voice acting is on the poor side of the scale. Overall, it is merely just an average game. Yes it is 5 years old at this point so take all of this with that into consideration. If it weren’t for the fun game play, I would have put this down as a negative review, however I will purely just recommend Hunted: The Demon’s Forge for purchase only when on sale. The game is retailing at £9, 99 but there are much better games of this genre out there for that price. 												the negativity at this games release hailed from people expecting something neither the dev-team nor the publisher of this glorious dungeon-crawler-pearl never promised. people expected another open-world-rpg ala Fallout or Eldar Scrolls.people saw "Bethesda" and simply jumped to conclousions. that out of way:Hunted is an amazing game.it's visual quality holds up pretty good, even today. the art-direction is more a dark/gritty type of fantasy which looks a) fantastic and b) gives this game a more mature touch. in some aspects the art-direction reminds me of Gears of War...yes sounds strange...Talking about Gears of War -> Hunted is pretty much a fantasy version of said game with more rpg-elements and loot.Combat feels great, no matter if you're takin cover and shooting enemies from a distance, blasting them with spells or hacking/blocking in melee range controls are always responsive and feel fluid. which is a good thing, cause apart from solving some simple puzzles or listening to great npc-dialogue you will be fighting most of the time.Inspite of the end-of-days Gears of War setting Hunted does feel like a classic dungeon-crawler come to live. But what sets this game realy apart from a simple action-game with steller production quality is the way the game is set up. Your basicaly never alone, the premise is two people and the game sticks with it. the great thing about this is that the AI doesn't suck, yes sometimes (realy seldom) there's a little path-finding issue, but in general you "feel" like playing with a another person, no matter if it's combat, exploring or a riddle your team is solving.The story centers on those two and is actualy not that bad, it's not the grand scheme of things which is important, but their relationship. you will chuckly hearing some their pockin at each other, you will feel attached to both after some time. especialy when playing singelplayer this game provides an amazing expierience simply from the fact of your companion. i've never played a game where my ai-companion felt that much alive/real and that is taking never Bioware games into account.Overall:-still realy good visuals-fantastic soundtrack, great voiceover (english)-tight controls, polished combat-an interesting story, which is more suited for mature players, both mainchars are not "heroes" and they show a real lack of empathie for anyone but themselves (which is a fantastic setup and i did love it, but not suited for minors)-an interesting gameworld and a great sense of exploring/dungeoncrawling-in general a great sense of polish and budget-one of the best integrations of an Ai-companion -creat two player co-op (but since game-spy is down you will have to read up on gettin co-op started)way underrated simply cause people expected something completly diffrent than the dev always promised. Hunted is like  one of those great old-school arpgs, immersive stroy and gameplay but not sporting a open world setting.

===This game no longer supports online co-op play as of the termination of GameSpy in May 31, 2014.===="Hunted is running through dungeon, killing monster with really cool swords, really cool weapons and amazing spells and magic special effects. It's a modern, co-op, cover-based, action game set in a rich dark fantasy world." - Matt Findley, President of InXile Entertainment.Although Hunted: The Demon's Forge may seems to be flawed and lacked in polish in many ways on the surface because its developer was focusing on the other bigger and more anticipated title of theirs, the core of Hunted: Demon's Forge capable of delivering is still considered to be the best by many co-op game players and dungeon crawlers across the world.There are many dungeon games out there - but none of them are quite like Hunted. Hunted has pretty much every good traditions and classic elements of the old school dungeon game such as riddles to solve, secret areas to explore and enemies that dungeon fans would expect to encouner. But with a big guy with sword, elven lady with bow and vicious creatures like minotaur and dragon. Hunted instead of being just a big cliché all over again, rather - it is more like mixing these clichés together in a dark fantasy world - and then throw it back onto your head with the qualities of modern platforms and human designs.After all, Hunted may be far from perfection in terms of presentation, bug-free, PC optimization, gameplay diversity and replayability. But this is also exactly why the sequel of it will be so promising and worthy after we see how good these things together turned out to be in the actual gameplay of Hunted. There will be just you, your partner; simple yet solid gameplay mechanics and a ton of straight forward hack-and-slash actions. And I just can't wait for a better sequel that unfolds the upcoming journey of our lovely mercenary pair - or - perhaps more like couple in blood, sweat and sarcasms.Recommended for dungeon srawlers or anyone who want some simple intuitive action gameplay. Better to play with a friend.----------------------------------------------------------------------------- For in-game actions: Even through a yet perfected and limited combat system, you can still tell that's how fast-paced hack-and-slash melee actions should be like in a thirdperson action game. As for bow and arrow, casting devastating magics and the boob jiggles whenever she bend over to pick up the money, those are extras. *Sorry, there aren't a ton of button smashing during cutscene in slow motion.- For overall presentation quality: Small detail in the environment may proves to be raw and very under polished (even at max settings.) But the voice lines as well as the interactions between our couple in the game tend to make you giggle and care less about these picky dissatisfactions.

												Hunted: The Demon’s Forge is a linear third-person adventure game featuring sword & shield combat combined with cover-based archery sections. Production values are high – voice-acting, music, and graphics quality (Unreal 3) are good – but can’t make up for how boring the game becomes. Travel by corridor, enter an arena, fight a horde of enemies, rinse, repeat. There are a few side-dungeons and puzzles which add much-needed variety (and are well-designed). The story is your standard snarky-adventurers-battle-orcs affair, but it never goes into too much depth, almost as though it’s only there as an excuse for the gameplay. Never a good sign. Oh, and if bikini warriors are something you like, one of the player-characters easily qualifies. If that’s the kind of thing that annoys you, well, prepare to be annoyed.Designed to be “king of co-op games,” co-op unfortunately doesn’t work since Gamespy was shut down. I’ve read in the forums that third-party apps will still enable cooperative play, but this seems hit-or-miss, and I haven’t tested it myself. Played solo, the campaign works well enough; your companion has plenty of health (though not invincible), and if powers are used consistently, the combat is easy. There is one tomb that bugs unless you play as the elf (as I discovered), and you can only switch between characters at specified points, and not at will (something that other co-op games manage without trouble). Magic feels a little cumbersome to use. Select the desired power using numbers 1-4 on your keyboard, and press Q to use the selected power. Why not have the number keys also use the power? It’s an extra key-stroke that isn’t appreciated in the heat of combat. There’s a rudimentary skill set and level-up system, but I collected so many points that upgrading was never something I thought much about.Hunted: The Demon’s Forge is easily a $20 game if everything works as advertised. That it is for sale at a list price of $5 indicates to me that Bethesda is aware of the issues but can’t be bothered to fix them, so the game is sold at a perpetual 75% discount. Worth a purchase IF you can get the co-op to work. For most of us, though, the time of Hunted: The Demon’s Forge has passed, and it’s not worth the asking price. Get it as cheap as possible if it tempts you, but be prepared to quickly move on to something else.Total size on my hard drive: 11GBNote about the final boss: The archer-player needs to shoot the boss in the heart, while the sword & shield player protects the archer from spawning enemies. When the heart-bar is depleted, the archer-player needs to shoot the enemy spawns, while the sword & shield player pushes on some columns. This will need to be done three or four times. Played in co-op, I don’t doubt it would work fine. Played solo, there is no way to issue orders to your companion about what (s)he should target, making victory rely on luck as much as skill. Frustrating.

												An entertaining dark fantasy hack and slash shoot em up. You follow a duo of mercenaries - E'lara, a rather scantily dressed elf with sick bow skills, and Caddoc, a buff-looking guy who loves to fight upclose and personal. Each one has their own style of fighting, with E'lara having a preference for ranged combat and Caddoc melee combat. The game lets you swap between them, so you can try them both out at various times and eventually settle for whoever you enjoy playing as more. Only thing I don't quite understand is that you can't swap between them whenever you want. Usually in games of this nature, the swapping is done at the press of a button, but here you can only swap when interacting with specific shrines.The combat is pretty fun and is very abundant. There is some variety in enemies and challenges presented and some fairly interesting boss fights. As you get through the game, you can learn some special skills too by unlocking them with magical crystals that you find in your travels. E'lara mostly has different types of arrows (exploding arrow, freezing arrow, and armour-piercing arrow), and Caddoc has brawl specials (powerful ramming, rage mode, and levitating enemies), and in addition to that, both can also learn various forms of magical spells.The story is ok, and though there are a few twists and turns present, it's mostly on the background and just gets you travelling between the locations and change the scenery. So if you're looking for a narrative-driven experience, you might be disappointed, but if you enjoy some fast-paced fighting with plenty of one-liners and witty dialogue exchanges, then you should enjoy it. Visuals, presentation, music, and voice acting are all pretty good and do their job. I think the whole setting is done pretty well. It's what you'd expect from a dark fantasy. Lots of grim-looking and ominous locations and horrendous (in a good way) creature designs. The levels are straight-forward and linear for the most part. There are occasionally interesting puzzles thrown in as well which change the pace a bit and get you exploring the area a bit.Overall I'd recommend this game. It's a fun way to spend a few hours and unwind. No over-complex mechanics or difficult decisions. Just fight some enemies, listen to witty dialogue, and enjoy the ride.

												Some games manage to slip under the radar, barely noticed because they are low profile or poorly marketed. Such is the case of Hunted: The Demon's Forge. Totally slipped under my radar not even doing a blip in passing. I discovered it only during a Steam sale and then a bunch of reasons pushed me to buy it. First, it was cheap, second it features one of my all time favorite video game female voice actress and then there was curiosity because the whole thing was developed by Brian Fargo's company inXile (and no, the skimpy outfit of the female protagonist was not a factor... well, barely).For those who don't know him, Brian Fargo is the mind behind the Wasteland franchise (most notably the recent Wasteland 2) and the original Fallout games (1 and 2). So when you relate Brian Fargo and PC games the first thing that comes to mind is "serious isometric hardcore RPG stuff".How does Hunted: The Demon's Forge fits in this conception? In absolutely no way. Not even close. It's not a RPG (despite featuring a skill tree) and although it could be in some regard qualified as "hardcore" it's certainly not isometric... nor serious. The closest description could be third person hack and slash/shooter with a RPG-ish veneer and a side of puzzles.But what it is above all is a fun way to spend time.The game is designed to be played in co-op, although it can perfectly be played in single player with little fuss with an AI handling of your partner OK although not terrific. Additionally to the main story, there are secret objectives, detours that can be found by going sideways. These involve puzzles, sometimes relatively hard ones;  and generally feature rewards that even if not necessary to complete the game can help.Hunted is a simple but fun game. Sure it won't gain any GOTY award nor be remembered as a major game 10 years from now but it makes for a fun diversion. And being fun is always a good thing for a game.

												Two poorly dressed mercenaries attempt to make some money, fail an intelligence test, fight their way past hordes of demons despite the constant distraction of jiggling breasts, a shiny bald head, various phobias, and personality disorders, but in the end, still make no money.It's actually not a terrible game, despite the metacritic score. The current Steam score of around 70% is more fair, I think. And considering its current single-digit price, it's hard not to recommend if it interests you at all.I've only played a few other Inxile games, but they seem to follow a trend: full of heart, mostly-competent technical/artistic merit, but gameplay mechanics balance done by a middle school kid.Granted, it only affects perhaps 20% of the game, but they tend to be the bigger fights, so it can be annoying. Annoyances include:- pixel-perfect aiming, but they give you a circle aiming reticle- enemies tend to move erratically, which is not great combined with the above, plus arrow travel time- a number of enemies have stun-lock or juggling attacks, at which point the only defense is to hope to get lucky with a dodge (no i-frames), or simply use a potion.- "challenge" tends to be of the formula: spawn lots of enemies, spawn the strongest enemies, surround the player. Pretty ham-fisted.- a few times, goes for one of the worst action game cardinal sins: unlimited respawning enemies.- literally pitch-black areas sometimes. Gamma adjust option doesn't work; no fix for this, as far as I can tell. Only light source tends to be lighting your weapon on fire, which goes out after you use it too much (at least as E'lara, the elf). Seriously stupid idea.- AI companion seems to go out of their way to deliberately block your path and shots, and even seems to mock you with various voice lines.That said, once you know how to deal with these, it's not so bad, as the two characters are given plenty of skills to use. Your AI-controlled partner seems to have pools of health and mana, so equipping them with skills is actually quite helpful. The infinite spawn segments aren't so great though, depending on the skills you have equipped and the difficulty level. Playing this game on the harder difficulties seems like masochism.It may sound like there's a lot of negative points, but if the game description and screenshots interest you at all, you'll probably like the game just fine. It's just that the gameplay mostly seems to feel like trying to exploit the enemy AI's dumb behavior rather than out-skilling it. Then again, sometimes it can be fun and powerful-feeling to mow down a bunch of enemies.Good points include:- decently long campaign for an action game; took me about 15 hours.- decent replayability; can play through with (or freely switch between) two characters, use different skills, or even the different character/weapon skins (more on that below). Plenty of stuff to look out for, which can improve abilities.- Fairly entertaining banter between the two mercs that reminds of Gimli and Legolas from the LOTR movies.- Surprisingly meaty side quest treasure hunts that are a lot like the newer Tomb Raider side areas, but possibly even bigger. Probably one of the best parts of the game.Final note: This game uses/used GameSpy for multiplayer and DLC redemption. GameSpy was shut down, and so this game has no official multiplayer support, nor can you redeem the pre-order DLC codes if you bought them. However, there are some work-arounds for multiplayer, although they look like a pain. It's also possible to download an existing save that has the DLC enabled, if you wish to play as Seraphine or use one of the other skins. Check the forums for more info.

												Hunted is a decent action-shooter following the story of two mercenaries, E'lara the elven archer and Caddoc the Swordsman out to make a fortune as their adventure takes them though desolate towns. ruins, dungeons and forests. The gameplay is pretty standard action fare, both characters carry a melee/shield combo and a ranged weapon  and these can be switched on the fly. They also have access to additional magic and skills that can be upgraded as the game progresses via finding crystals. Combat is quite good initially (especially using the bow with E'lara) but does become quite repetitive as you move through the chapters with each enemy encounter being similar to the last. Puzzle's also suffer the same fate. There are a few occasions when some set pieces are thrown in to try and add some variety such as forcing you to run rather than fight or defend an area with a ballista, but these are not enough to make up for the other shortcomings. Overall the gameplay is not bad but not great either. I recommend playing with a friend in co-op if possible as this does make it more enjoyable. Now for the stronger aspects.. Firstly the characters! These two are by far the strongest element of this game. They are entertaining and are permitted some character development as the story unfolds. A particular highlight is the banter between the pair that's littered throughout. The story itself was interesting and kept me playing to the conclusion (of which there are 3 endings) and there was a lot of potential in the world that has been created here, although that potential is never fully tapped into.Overall I still give this game a recommendation and as it can be found online for under £10 is worth a run through for anyone looking for a dark fantasy fix or some co-op action (or both!).Score:Playing Solo 6/10Playing Co-op 7/10

												I am very pleasantly surprised by this game. So much so, that I feel comfortable giving it a positive riview despite the fact that I have not gotten so far into the game.While the graphics were not above average even when it was published, this is only a minor flaw, outshined greatly by the story and character. The two protaganists are fun to listen to interact, and are thankfully not the standard fantasy trope of wild yet wise elf and impulsive yet stoic human. Caddoc (human) and E'lara (elf) almost give the impression of an affectionate married couple, bickering good-naturedly with one another yet always supportive. The characters are flawed, real, and interesting. Few games do character interaction better. The story is darker and grimier than most fantasy, which contrasts nicely with the character's general optimism. The player is given the impression that if the characters were not so, that the darkness would swallow them up.The game does not have heavy RPG elements, but what there is have been done competently. The voice acting is done well.The control scheme leaves a bit to be desired, and navigating menus is clunky. If you enjoy lore scraps in the vein of Dark Souls or Victor Vran, this is the game for you; however, certain 'entries' such as monster lore appear to one-time shots with no way to go back and view after the first time, and it is easy to miss it entirely.Hunted is well worth the purchase, particularly at its current price point.

												This one is a definite no. As others have said there's no online anymore, but we had tunggle set up to use the LAN so I'll consider that a minor issue just mentioning it incase it's more of a problem for others.Even though there's magic, ranged and melee characters are basically stuck in one role. The warriors crossbow sucks, and the elfs melee equally so. Expect to stay in the one role if you're playing that class. There are set points (purple crystals) that you can switch characters. The magic largely sucks too, there are 3 unique spells for each class then 3 they share. During my time playing there were only 2 worth using and the others are just pointless wastes of mana. The warrior only gets 3 different weapon types: Sword which is fastest and weakest, axe which is middle ground, and club which is highest damage but slow. The speed makes more of a difference in my opinion so again 90% of the game with a sword made the combat have almost no variation to it.The systems are super clunky. The enchanted weapons have set amounts of charges, so they'll do really high damage for about a single fight then usually drop to worse damage than unenchanted items. The shields have durability which gets eaten away very quickly with blocking making them feel like they're made of cardboard. Some shields have armor stats with them and there's a single slot for armor (a pauldron of all things) but the game gives no indication of what armor is worth and it seems to make very little difference. Magic can only be leveled at special white cricles but since magic is so bad it feels pointless to limit leveling it up. There are collectables that feel like a chore, like deathstones that gives background story but since you'll care so little about the story these are pointless, people you can save which serve the same purpose, and gold. That's right gold is a freaking collectable! We were picking it up hoping it would help us when we got to buy something but no, it doesn't do anything it, just fills up a bar in your menu. Also you can only hold at most 3 of every potion type, this means you'll constantly alternate between having almost none to being surrounded by potions you can't pick up and have to leave behind to go through the next gate. There are also executions in this game but they are also worthless. The only people you can execute are basically dead anyway, so doing the execution would just waste time when you could've just hit them one more time. This is especially true if you're using a slow weapon.The graphics aren't great. The voice acting isn't either. The dialog is terrible, rather than two mercenary partners they end up sounding like 2 people who are forced to be together by some common goal. They say maybe 3 mildly funny things through the entire story. You'll also constantly pass people standing off the the side talking to themselves in a loop of dialog which adds nothing to the game and gets pretty annoying half way through. The story is trash *Spoilers* Some dragon hunter gets corrupted by sleg (the child of soylent green and mercury), leads some orcs to war and you stop him, bad ending if you drink sleg during any of the survival fights, good if you don't.Lastly, the game is painfully linear. I'm fine with linear games, especially ones that focus on story, but this game basically pushed you through it. Constant sections that are a few feet long at best. There was always a tiny ledge you couldn't climb after you jumped or a door it wouldn't let you go through again that would stop you from back tracking even the slightest bit. The result makes you feel like you're just passing through a bunch of ready checks since you can't proceed through them without your partner there and they're LITTERED throughout every map. This discouraged any attempt to explore since you could rarely go anywhere off the path. The rare exception was the 4 "Puzzles" and these are puzzles in the loosest sense. They usually consist of finding something to open a door than solving how to open the door. Then they would end with a skeleton fight. Completing the first 3 lets you do the 4th one and doing the 4th gives each character a weapon. Excluding bosses there are only 3 types of enemies, orcs (wargoth); minotaurs; and skeletons. The orcs would use bows and had one special one that used magic but mostly all enemies are just melee of slight variations (Armor/no armor, sheild/no shield, duel wielding). The boss fights are terrible too, for example one is a spider you just run from until you reach a balista and shoot a rock so it falls on it, and you're done.P.S. this game glitches too. The last boss involves pushing down pillars that heal him whenever he tries to use them. We could easily have done this but it took about 4-5 tries because the game refused to let me push them down. Some animations bug. I tried pushing a cart and my character looked sideways instead so it didn't give me the push button mash prompt. When I finished a melee chain I would sometimes teleport to the other side of the enemy I was fighting. The most common glitch was with the door based ready checks. One person lifts the door and the other goes and helps lift it the rest of the way, but maybe 30-40% of the time one of us would move into position like we were going to lift it but wouldn't, then they'd just stand like that for a while until they set the door back down and we could try again.All in all this game isn't worth it in my opinion. I got it on sale and only payed $3 for 2 copies of the game, but there are so many problems with it it's ridiculous. You won't be missing anything if you skip this one.

Posted: December 16, 2012
												I was pleasantly surprised by this game. Everything I heard about it was mediocre, and while I can't really disagree, the game was enjoyable all the way through. The graphics are not the greatest. but the texture work in this game is actually rather impressive at times. The music and sound are well-done too, although I had a strange bug where the sound effects (not voice) were WAY louder than everything else. The sarcastic dialog back and forth between the characters was pretty hilarious at times.The gameplay was very frustrating at times though. When you get hit by enemies, they stunlock you for a decent amount of time, making it almost guaranteed that they'll hit you again. In parts with a lot of fast-moving enemies, it is entirely possible to get more or less trapped by a group of 3 enemies. It is extremely frustrating at times. The boss fight with the dragon was particularly bad.Speaking of boss fights, a lot of the ones you encounter throughout the game will come back many times over in future battles. It's kind of a cheap mechanic.Controls work pretty well, but if you play as E'lara, sometimes it can really seem like the bow aiming is punishingly difficult. Not that it's hard to aim, but that you'll be aimed dead-on in close range, and miss over and over and over and over. It's particularly noticeable against the stupid little spider enemies, which by the way will demolish E'lara.The AI is absolutely horrible, too. I played mostly as E'lara, and the AI-controlled Caddoc would refuse to engage tough enemies with melee, so they would chase me down and destroy me. Also, he would repeatedly run ahead and smash open the enchanted weapon cases, so I couldn't get the weapon inside. I understand that he needs weapons too, but it would be nice to have the choice in my hands.The little events where you and your partner both have to hit a button and "traverse" an area, such as opening a door or jumping over a pit, are incredibly arbitrary and stupid. For the most part it's not a big deal, but the first few times you miss an explorable area because you can't backtrack will annoy you.The game is decent overall. Definitely has its problems, but if you're looking for a co-op adventure, you can pick this up for cheap enough now that it's worth it.

												5/10The Good:This is a very beautiful game. The graphics are very pleasing for the characters and the architecture. The level designers should be given top marks. There are lots of secrets to explore and find along with plenty of change of scenery and triggers along the way so that each enemy encounter is different, and exciting. The design of the game is really quite nice from the skill system, and how you upgrade them to a solid quick combat moving from ranged to melee with ease.The Bad:Who ever did the lightning did a terrible job, there are huge areas of the game that have zero lighting at all so you just bump against walls and hope you find your way through, even with gamma turned all the way to the top. There is an a ton of bugs that I encountered in my 2-3 hour play time which was mostly pertaining to my companion not staying with me and getting stuck on terrain or other parts.. and just stood there.  The ranged combat system is working nicely except the DPI is set to super low and it's very hard to get a viable headshot if you are manually shooting. The melee combat system is pretty much useless because blocking is nearly impossible due to no lock on system or it does not allow you to back pedal while blocking to reposition for proper blocking. If you are holding right click to block, and press S to attempt to back up to face the enemy properly, you instead turn and walk away from them, showing your back, giving them easy hits.The design is great, the graphics are great, the level design is great.Lighting is poor, lots of bugs, combat system is poor.5/10 Would not reccomend.

Teal DeerDevelopers: inXile Entertainment Publishers: Besthesda SoftworksInitial release: May 2011Genre: Action, 3rd person shooter(TPS), Co-op#Worth/NotWorth: #MedicoreAndBoringNotWorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationI have a soft spot in my heart for certain B-tier action titles. Hunted seemed it would be that cheesy generic game that was so dumb it was endearing. Turns out, its just dumb. Hunted is a cooperatively based action adventure. One female elf and one human male. I played it single player and made no attempt to see what it was like with another person. My guess is not much improved.Mechanically, its poor; the ranged combat has trouble with hit detection and the melee combat feels sluggish. Its linear, hallway into arena combat. Rinse an repeat. The voice acting is less than stellar. I swear to you I was less than 20 minutes in and the same audio had repeated 3 times.  Another odd thing is the puzzles sometimes require a specific character to do them but you can't switch on the fly between them. You have to do it at a crystal and the game seems to make a big deal about it. Making some of the puzzles quite literally pointing and telling the AI to do it. The AI is also very fond of getting your way during combat. There is also some dialogue recorded for such instances when the characters end up smushing into one another that is VERY annoying and down right cringey. THE GISTI'm not sure why so many positive reviews. I mean, its at best functional. The story is immediately forgettable and the mechanics work to the degree that if you were to drop a bowling ball from considerable height, its likely to make a loud noise when dropped regardless of what surface it hits; but you probably don't want to hear that noise.Follow my curation for more
